title: How did the American and French Revolutions differ on the onset of revolution? - Quora

response.answer_text: The American Revolution inspired the French Revolution - it showed that a country based on Enlightenment ideas and free of kings and lords could work. French intellectuals sought to imitate the US success but failed. 90% of what made the US work was in place before the War of Independence - in practice there were no Lords or Kings and there were state elected assemblies with existing constitutions, etc. etc. whereas France was full of vested interests of many sorts and had a much more difficult task. So it failed, first into Empire and then into a restoration of the monarchy

Both were started by angry radicals. The French Revolution degenerated into random social violence which is never constructive and led, inevitability to Napoleon. By comparison, the American Revolution led to a much more peaceful, if feckless, period of constructive efforts under the Articles of Confederation intended to create a status of cultural and economic normalcy…which failed but led led directly to the Constitutional Convention of 1787…which succeeded admirably. In short, the war was started by fire breathing radicals, but won, eventually, by more practical visionary leaders with more constructive saner intentions. Essentially, businessmen, not street thugs.

The most important difference is that the American Revolution created a Republic guided by the United States Constitution, a constitution that has governed the United States for over 225 years without any break in regular free elections. Under the U.S. Constitution, the United States grew into the most powerful and wealthiest nation in the world.  The French Revolution, on the other hand, created first chaos and bloody terror, then the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars, followed by further changes in the French form of government about every 15 to 20 years until the present. France declined in world power, lost the Franco-Prussian War, was exhausted by WW1 and was conquered and occupied by Nazi Germany in WW2.

The main difference is that the American Revolution didn’t morph into a killing frenzy that sent people in opposition to be shortened by a head. The American version also produced a stable republican structure that has remained basically functional for two centuries plus and helped facilitate the nation rising to a preeminent position on the world stage. The the French model, on the other hand, has gone through many evolutions including two dictatorships and several republics and has led to a nation greatly reduced in influence and power on the world stage.

There was no American revolution; there was a war of independence, to permit the American population to govern itself. The only thing that changed was where the orders came from and who made them. In France, there was a revolution: a monarchy was destroyed and replaced, eventually, by an entirely different form of government: democracy. The Ancien Regime became totally extinct. That didn’t happen in the American case. There was really very little social change; life went on pretty much as before, but with a different allegiance, that’s all: same elites, same customs, virtually the same laws. In France the government was changed, the political system was changed, the legal system was changed, the social system was changed; in short, France underwent a revolution. Vive la Revolution!

The most important difference was that the US was a nonthreatening backwater at the time. When France declared itself a Republic, every country in Europe and some parts of France itself declared war on it, so between the foreign and civil wars France was involved in, the country was fighting a war on twelve fronts. This led to the Terror, because from two directions the countries at war with France could get to Paris very easily (from the Vendee, Britain could get in, and the Vendee was making no secret that they were inviting French aristocracy who had fled to England in; and from Alsace-Lorraine), and people from there could easily came into Paris (as evidenced by the Girondine Charlotte Cordet coming and stabbing Marat).

The Americans were fighting the British for freedom, for independence. The French revolution was about rebelling against tyranny, and social inequality, and it was inspired by Enlightenment thinkers like Voltaire, Rousseau and John Locke. The French revolution was from 1789 to 1799. The American Revolution was from 1765 to 1783.

The Americanhad the skilled people to stop the revolution. The French kept going, even after it addressed the fundamental grievances that ignited it Each increase in radicalization lead to a darker and darker place until the only same response was a return to what was before The French revolution was more egalitarian, more humane than the American but it lost control to the radical leftists (history does repeat)

One was a revolution, which overthrew the existing system of government & brought in a new one. Laws, administration etc. were radically overhauled, from top to bottom. The other was a war of separation. Existing structures almost all stayed in place, but with outsiders at the top replaced by locals, with new methods of appointing them.

The American revolution was a conservative movement designed to protect the status quo. The French revolution was a “real” revolution as it was meant to change the existing ruling structure and replace it with something else.

Another fundamental difference, in addition to what’s already been written, was that despite the names, one was a revolution, the other was a war of secession. In a revolution, the people try to overthrow the existing government. That’s what happened in France. Never during the War for Independence did the colonies ever try to unseat King George III. It was a war of secession from the British empire.
